text:
apache on my machine crashs very often, several times a day (more info in this 
bug report: http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22631 )
and every time it does that, rotatelogs.exe (both of them) stays in memory.
When Apache restarts, two new rotatelogs.exe being started. At the end of week 
I have ower 50 rotatelogs.exe in memory...
creator: spam@come.no-ip.com
chip@force-elite.com
text: Does this still happen with 2.0.50?

creator: robert@tweerlei.de
text:
This is still an issue in 2.0.54, at least on Win32.
When viewing the process tree, it seems that the rotatelogs are children of the
child process. If this process exits (e.g. due to some module calling exit, as
in my case), the rotatelogs persist.
The results differ: Sometimes, they simply stay around, but sometimes they seem
to lock the logfiles, so rotatelogs spawned by the new child keep crashing,
filling the error log with thousands of "rotatelogs terminated unexpectedly"
messages.

Some more info:
I put an exit(1) into worker_main (mpm_winnt's child.c) that kills the process
on each new connection.
Then I set up three virtual hosts with ErrorLog and CustomLog piped to rotatelogs.
After starting, there are 12 rotatelogs.exe alive.
After making a connection (and thus causing the child to exit), the child
process is restarted, but the number of rotatelogs.exe increases to 15.
Same after next connection (18).
After terminating the main process with ctrl-c, those additional 6 processes
remain active.
creator: robert@tweerlei.de
robert@tweerlei.de
text:
Even more info:
The rotatelogs processes that 'survive' are those writing the access logs for
the 3 virtual hosts.

This affects me running Apache 2.0.55 on Windows 2003 Server as well. For me,
rotatelogs.exe always will keep running, even when restarting or shutting down
the Apache process.

This issue: http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24805
mentions a patch only for the prefork worker - perhaps it's not fixed for mpm_winnt?
creator: lgl@leia.org
jpetrakis@rcn.com
text:
It does this more often than anyone here thinks... for me, every time you cycle
the server, it leaves rotatelogs running, then, when it re-starts, it dumps *two
more* because of some odd failure (that does not get reported).  So even if I
just restart, I'm left with four zombie rotatlogs processes.

I have 2.0.55 running on Windows 2000 and I'm experiencing this as well.  My
experience is very similar to the one outlined here:
http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26467#c12
As that posted stated, I also have Win32DisableAcceptEx set (though I have no
idea if it's related or not).
creator: wakkow1@gmail.com
apache@bakerweb.biz
text:
Someone should change summary to reflect that rotatelogs stays loaded even after
Apache is normally terminated. In my case it is 10 rotatelogs.exe processes that
get started based on two log file lines in httpd.conf and they remain loaded
when the Apache service is stopped.

creator: fleger@siderlog.fr
text: This is very anoying, does someone have a fix ?

Could the developers please at least post that they have seen this bug and 
intend to fix/ignore it?  I'm running Apache 2.2.2 on WindowsXP.  We're all 
too dumb here to use linux, so a fix/workaround for the windows version would 
be most appreciated.  I have only two virtual hosts (one for ssl) and I've 
just rebooted and started apache and now I've got 12 processes.  If I restart 
Apache, I get more yet processes.  I'm going nuts here.  Does anybody have a 
reccomended program/python code to kill these things?
creator: litewerk@gmail.com
trash_bin@nurfuerspam.de
text: (In reply to comment #10) > Could the developers please at least post that they have seen this bug Although (or should I write: since) it seems that no one wants do deal with the problem I would suggest focusing on mod_log_rotate. Apparently the only thing this module lacks at the moment is such code that parses "%Y-%m-%d" tokens in the target filename, like rotatelogs(.exe) does. Currently mod_log_rotate can only produce "name.NNN" formatted filenames, where NNN are seconds since 1970. On the other hand, it already has the local time handling coming with newer versions of Apache's rotatelogs. I've already asked the developer for doing that and he reported he's got sent a patch concerning this, and will work on it in the near future. If this will be become true, mod_log_rotate IMHO could be the perfect (hopefully platform-independent) replacement/alternative for the piping method. I personnally would appreciate if mod_log_rotate becomes part of Apache then. However, it probably would be a good idea to encourage Andy (the developer) to do the outstanding work.

creator: andy@hexten.net
text:
> However, it probably would be a good idea to encourage Andy 
> (the developer) to do the outstanding work.

Done :)

mod_log_rotate now supports stfrtime() formatting.

(In reply to comment #12)
> mod_log_rotate now supports stfrtime() formatting.

Thanks a lot, Andy.

http://hexten.net/mod_log_rotate

Albeit, it's very worrying and irritating that still
NO ONE of the Apache developers seemed to give even
the smallest acknowledgment to the problem itself.
creator: trash_bin@nurfuerspam.de

text:
I don't meet this problem on and after Apache 2.0.55 on Windows XP and Windows
2003. However, it comes out again on version 2.2.x.
creator: athensy@hotmail.com

text:
Just want to confirm that this bug still exists in Apache 2.2.3 
(and Windows 2003 Enterprise Server) which makes it more or less unusable.
creator: sko@pool.math.tu-berlin.de
jorton@redhat.com
text:
The symptoms described here are rather similar to that in bug 40651 but I don't
know if that bug is really a separate Unix-specific issue.  Can someone try this
patch to see if it fixes the problem for Win32 too?

http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/httpd/httpd/trunk/server/log.c?r1=452431&r2=452430&pathrev=452431&view=patch

creator: apache@keithtyler.com
text:
mod_log_rotate is not an adequate replacement as it can/does not rotate
error_logs. See http://www.sitebuddy.com/mod_log_rotate .

As http://www.sitebuddy.com/Apache/Rotatelogs.exe/Bug indicates that this is
also a problem with Cronolog, perhaps the problem actually lies in the handling
of piped logs under Windows.
creator: apache@keithtyler.com
tonyg@guadagno.org
text:
(In reply to comment #16)
> The symptoms described here are rather similar to that in bug 40651 but I don't
> know if that bug is really a separate Unix-specific issue.  Can someone try this
> patch to see if it fixes the problem for Win32 too?
> 
>
http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/httpd/httpd/trunk/server/log.c?r1=452431&r2=452430&pathrev=452431&view=patch

I compiled 2.2.3 source with ssl and zlib and a patched log.c (above).  I was
able to start the httpd as an application, but not as a service.  When I tried,
it would complain about not being able to write log files.
As a verification, I reverted the log.c and recompiled.  the result worked as
expected..functioning fine except for the orphaned log processes

(In reply to comment #17)
> mod_log_rotate is not an adequate replacement as it can/does not rotate
> error_logs. See http://www.sitebuddy.com/mod_log_rotate .

I second this comment, I had high hopes for mod_log_rotate, until I discovered
that you cannot rotate error logs with it.
creator: tonyg@guadagno.org

text:
(In reply to comment #19)
> (In reply to comment #16)

http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/httpd/httpd/trunk/server/log.c?r1=452431&r2=452430&pathrev=452431&view=patch
> 
> I compiled 2.2.3 source with ssl and zlib and a patched log.c (above).  I was
> able to start the httpd as an application, but not as a service.  When I tried,
> it would complain about not being able to write log files.
> As a verification, I reverted the log.c and recompiled.  the result worked as
> expected..functioning fine except for the orphaned log processes

Ok, I found a post ( http://www.apachelounge.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=568 )
where someone suggested this:
>Looks like there's a bug in server/log.c in function piped_log_spawn
>((status = apr_procattr_cmdtype_set(procattr,
>APR_SHELLCMD_ENV)) != APR_SUCCESS) ||
>
>should read
>
>((status = apr_procattr_cmdtype_set(procattr,
>APR_PROGRAM_ENV)) != APR_SUCCESS)
>
>After this patch, when you close the main program, the piped processes are also
>killed off.

I applied the suggestion to log.c and recompiled.  The result fixed one of two
issues I see.
1.  for every log pipe (rotatelogs.exe) spawned, there is a corrisponding
cmd.exe in the task manager
  This was not effected by the patch
2.  when apache exits, or in some cases, when logs rotate; the piped program
(rotatelogs.exe) are not shut down and live on.
  This was FIXED by the change, they now exit when apache exits.

anyone have any ideas on the first issue?

thanks
creator: tonyg@guadagno.org
rpluem@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #21)

> 
> Ok, I found a post ( http://www.apachelounge.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=568 )
> where someone suggested this:
> >Looks like there's a bug in server/log.c in function piped_log_spawn
> >((status = apr_procattr_cmdtype_set(procattr,
> >APR_SHELLCMD_ENV)) != APR_SUCCESS) ||
> >
> >should read
> >
> >((status = apr_procattr_cmdtype_set(procattr,
> >APR_PROGRAM_ENV)) != APR_SUCCESS)
> >
> >After this patch, when you close the main program, the piped processes are also
> >killed off.
> 
> I applied the suggestion to log.c and recompiled.  The result fixed one of two
> issues I see.
> 1.  for every log pipe (rotatelogs.exe) spawned, there is a corrisponding
> cmd.exe in the task manager
>   This was not effected by the patch
> 2.  when apache exits, or in some cases, when logs rotate; the piped program
> (rotatelogs.exe) are not shut down and live on.
>   This was FIXED by the change, they now exit when apache exits.

By which change? The one Joe mentioned in comment #16 or the one mentioned on
www.apachelounge.com?

> 
> anyone have any ideas on the first issue?

This is caused by using APR_SHELLCMD_ENV instead of APR_PROGRAM_ENV. But it is
an ongoing discussion whether this is a bug or a feature. Unix people tend more
to the idea of that being a feature whereas windows people are more likely to
see this as a bug.

see http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23616#c19 , Joe's
suggestion did not work.  The apachelounge suggestion works to solve the issue
about the rotatelogs not exiting when apache exits.  So I don't understand your
comment.  I am using APR_PROGRAM_ENV now.  whether using APR_PROGRAM_ENV or
APR_SHELLCMD_ENV i get one cmd.exe process for each rotatelogs process.  Any way
to get rid of them?  or is that just the way it is?

creator: rpluem@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #23)
 > By which change? The one Joe mentioned in comment #16 or the one mentioned on
> > www.apachelounge.com?
> see http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23616#c19 , Joe's
> suggestion did not work.  The apachelounge suggestion works to solve the issue

Hm, strange. This patch is part of 2.2.4 and I am pretty sure that it has been
tested to start as a service. Could you please give 2.2.4 a try?

> about the rotatelogs not exiting when apache exits.  So I don't understand your
> comment.  I am using APR_PROGRAM_ENV now.  whether using APR_PROGRAM_ENV or

My understanding was that APR_PROGRAM_ENV avoids starting a shell on Unix /
cmd.exe on Windows (see
http://apr.apache.org/docs/apr/1.2/group__apr__thread__proc.html#ggdcb981d7748c580eb69ac11dbf7090606a3f9694aced0e449f6bb4b3e437233a),
but maybe my understanding of APR here is wrong.

creator: tonyg@guadagno.org

text:
The same problem (rotatelogs.exe not terminated when httpd is stopped or
restarted) is still there on 2.2.4. I have changed APR_SHELLCMD_ENV to
APR_PROGRAM_ENV in both places in log.c as suggested in #21 and it also works
for me. Among other things, the full filename of the executable has to be
specified in ErrorLog / CustomLog lines.
This used to work, but will not work anymore:
    ErrorLog "|bin/rotatelogs xxxx/logs/error_log_%Y%m%d.log 86400"
This works:
    ErrorLog "|bin/rotatelogs.exe xxxx/logs/error_log_%Y%m%d.log 86400"

Is it possible to mark this bug as OPEN and attempt to fix this for the next
release?
creator: JPlissonneauDuquene@bellhelicopter.textron.com

text:
I am quite curious, when or even if anybody will fix this issue.

I see that this bug already exists for a long time (Apache 2.0.x and Apache 
2.2.x series). The way it was described by several Windows OS users exactly 
matches my experiences on a Windows 2003 Server system.

If a software wants to be somewhat 'platform idependent', it should try to fix 
a problem of that extent. It is not only that it is annoying to see a growing 
number of orphaned processes everytime you change your configuration, but a 
really makes you angry, if the logs aren't continued for some reason, if the 
number of hanging processes has grown to much. And if you rely on log rotation 
for log analysis, it can break your neck if it is part of a contract with an 
important customer.

I really would appreciate that some of the developers may state that this is 
by design and the design will not change (hopefully not) or give it another 
try...

And hopefully there will not be any "MS Windows bashing" like "use Linux, dumb 
mate". Sometimes you don't have the choice and this shouldn't be a matter of 
OS choice.

Apache is great, just make it a little greater...

(Sorry for any bad expression)
creator: robert.neumann@3dgeo.de
nick@webthing.com
text:
There were some log-rotation fixes in 2.2.6.  Can you test that, and report back
whether they affect this issue?

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
No response from submittor, presuming issue is resolved at 2.2.6, and note that
2.2.7 contains additional robustness corrections for win32 piped logging.
